so the first thing what you are going to
need is a miniature we went for the
Millennium Falcon if you want to stay in
the Star Wars theme but you can do this
with every miniature you want next let's
place our camera and frame these shots
we went for a normal wide shot on a
tripod after we are ready let's take the
empty shot to play the miniature and as
you can see we made sure that no cars
were in the shot which will give no
reference points to word size of other
vehicles okay next up is the miniature
and its movements we are going to film
it an exact same location as our empty
this will make sure that the lighting
matches for the movement we are going to
use a motion control slider which will
give us complete control over the
movement and will make it much easier
however you can also use fishing wire if
you don't have a motion control slider
it will be harder but it will work so
position your miniature quite close to
the lens and align the perspective with
the background do this for your begin
position and for your end position after
we have our movement planned out let's
add a green screen in the background now
the last thing before you can shoot as
the aperture because we are so close to
the lens we have a shallow depth of
field by closing the aperture the depth
of field will become bigger this will
make the whole Millennium Falcon sharp
okay make your shot and let's load them
both in Premiere Pro the first thing you
can do now is place the empty on the
first rack and a miniature shot on track
number 4 now let's remove the green
within the effect library search for the
Elder Archaea effect and drag that to
the miniature chops in the effects
control panel you can now take the color
selector and select the green if needed
you can do some extra adjustments in the
settings after this you will have your
miniature keyed out for the biggest part
the rest you can remove with a simple
mask that you can animate so it follows
your ship then the only thing you need
to do is scale and position it to really
match your scene as you can see the clip
is too long this is because the movement
is very slow to fix this we can use a
speed ramp technique so right click on
the FX button from the miniature clip
select time remapping and then speed
look for the point where your spaceships
almost lands on the ground and here you
can create a keyframe on the clip with
the pen tool you can already pull the
keyframe open to the left to give it a
smooth easy end
then take the line on the left of
keyframe and drag it all the way up to
speed it up this will already make the
movements fast but still not fast enough
so if you want it faster
you have to nest the clip and do all the
speed ramping again after all this you
will already have a cool shot of your
ship landing so now let's add some
details the first thing we are going to
add is the heat radiating from the ship
to create this duplicate the empty shot
to track number two from the effects
library you can now drag the turbulent
displace effect through the duplicates
and the effects controls you can now
play around with the settings we just
increased the amount and decrease the
size but most importantly we animated
evolution over the entire clip this will
make your heat wave move and make it
more realistic however the heat waves
are now over the complete footage so
next go to the opacity property and take
the pen tool create a mask to single out
some ways under the ship with a simple
rectangle after you make your mask
feather the bunch and enable the
animation for the mask pads now go
further in time and let your mouth
follow your ship if the heat waves are
maybe a little bit too hard you can
always lower the opacity for them next
let's do the shadow in your project
panel you can create a new item which
will be a color matte then drag this
color matte to the third track first we
are going to add a ramp effect to the
color mat to give it a gradient and your
ramp setting you can make the start
color a dark blue and the end color
light gray also change your ramp shape
to radial ramp we do this because the
center of the shadow will always be
darker than the outsides next move
further in time where your spaceship
landed here you can create an ellipse
mask on the color mat under the ship
again feather it a bunch set the
blending mode to hard light and maybe
even lower the opacity now because your
ship flies in the shadow also needs to
come in so on the point where your ship
is down you can enable the animation for
the mask bat feather and opacity here
the shadow needs to be the hardest and
the darkest so when going back in time
when your ship is in the air the shadow
needs to be bigger softer and lighter
you can animate these three settings to
the extent that you find realistic
which will give you this result now to
really sell the effect you can add some
dust waves or smoke and of course a lens
flare because what's the current Star
Wars movie without any lens flash and if
you really want to top it off you can
also add a fake hand out motion to it
all just simply use an adjustment layer
above everything and add a fake handheld
preset of ours to the adjustment layer
and that's it
